abstract: Although Samsung can’t entice people to wait in line like Apple fans for a new phone, the company can fight back with advertising. Enter the new sure-to-go-viral video by Samsung: “Why Wait? The Next Big Thing Is Already Here.” The ad pokes fun at Apple while showcasing the Samsung Galaxy S II, a 4G Android phone with a large 4.3-inch screen.
snippet: Although Samsung can’t entice people to wait in line like Apple fans for a new phone, the company can fight back with advertising. Enter the new sure-to-go-viral video by Samsung: “Why Wait? The Next Big Thing Is Already Here.” The ad pokes fun at...
lead_paragraph: Waiting in line for new Apple products has become a rite of passage for many trendy types these days. New iPhones and iPads are met with people camping out for days, hoping to be the first to procure a new Apple anything.

headline.main: Samsung Pokes Fun at Apple in Phone Ad

abstract: The United States Patent and Trademark Office in Alexandria, Va., recently unveiled an exhibit of 30 giant iPhone-like models honoring the inventions of the late Steve Jobs. Each iPhone model displays patents that list Mr. Jobs as inventor or co-inventor.

lead_paragraph: The United States Patent and Trademark Office in Alexandria, Va., recently unveiled an exhibit of 30 giant iPhone-like models honoring the inventions of the late Steve Jobs.

abstract: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Tanzina Vega, the Times reporter covering digital advertising, explains how BrightTag’s One Click Privacy works for Web surfers. Phil Simon discusses his new book, “The Age of the Platform: How Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google Have Redefined Business.”
snippet: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Tanzina Vega, the Times reporter covering digital advertising, explains how BrightTag’s One Click Privacy works for Web surfers. Phil Simon discusses his new book, “The Age of the Platform: How Amazon, Apple, Face...
lead_paragraph: As the World Wide Web Consortium and the Federal Trade Commission work to create a Do Not Track standard for consumers’ online privacy, some companies are trying out their own methods to give Web surfers more control over what personal data sites can collect. Tanzina Vega, a reporter on the Times media desk, explains how BrightTag’s new One Click Privacy button works.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Great Big Privacy Buttons
